There is a strong tendency in science to focus on **matter** and **motion**.
For example, temperature can be explained based on knowledge of the mass
of molecules and their velocity.

## Epistemic Reductionism

> The idea that all explanations ultimately reduce to physics:
> what is the nature of the matter and the extent of its motion?

::: {.fragment .fade-up}
::: {.callout-important}

## Food Science & Technology

The above concept is important for simple systems and also philosophically interesting.
Practically speaking, however, we often must study properties at a macro-scale. 

Food as a biological entity has a complex and varied structure. As a technology it is
manufactured, stored, marketed, distributed, sold and consumed.

:::
:::

## Biomimetics

> The mimicking of natural biological structures in the design of functional materials

::: {.callout}
There are specific reasons we might want to replace meat (see sustainability).
By studying real meat closely we can determine how to replace it effectively.
An important aspect is recreating the fibrous structure of meat.
This is less important in products like burgers and nuggets,
which have a a more uniform structure due to processing.

**The solution is more complex than "just use protein".**
:::

## Biomimetics: Other Examples

- Infant formula
- Fat substitutes
- Milk replacement

::: {.callout-note}

The idea is not simply that "nature is better".

It is `there are cases when natural structures can inform design`.

A vegan food designer has as much to learn from milk is a dairy scientist.

:::
